title: Workshop 3: How to do a winning pitch (2024)

transcript.text: Hi students, my name is Emily Zaborski
and today I will be talking to you about
how to pitch your startup idea.
So let's start with the basics. What is
a pitch? Well, it's a way to communicate
to and convince others that your idea is
worth backing. Usually, this is when
startups are looking for investment, but
it can also be used when trying to
convince industry experts or partners to
jump on board, or in your case, to show
a panel of judges that your idea has
potential as part of a competition. What
it should be is short and concise,
delivers a story, defines the problem,
and is engaging, and it sparks interest
so that people want to know more. What
it should not be is an opportunity to
share every concept or feature you can
think of. It shouldn't be boring or
contenheavy or confusing.
This is also a way to show investors or
partners who you are, why they should
trust what you're telling them, and why
should they want to work with you.
Remember, most of the time you're
pitching to someone, they are completely
new and they have no idea what you're
trying to achieve. It's easy to fall
into a trap as a startup founder to
assume that people understand your
vision. And when you're thinking about
your concept day in day out, you forget
to go back to the very basics.
Essentially, this should be your why.
And in truth, every company started
somewhere. Those big brands that we now
know and love would have used similar
techniques to the ones we will cover
today. So let's see if we can identify
these three companies based on their
first ever pitch decks.
So this company here says the problem is
price is an important concern for
customers booking travel online. Hotels
leave you disconnected from the city and
its culture and there's no easy way to
book a home with a local or become a
host. The solution was a web platform
where users could rent out their space
to host travelers.
and they provided some information about
the market size. 630,000
that are on temporary housing site couch
surfing.com
and 17,000 temporary house listings on
Craigslist between 20 July 2009 and July
They've provided a bit more about the
total market size across the world and
right down um to trips
and a bit about the product with a bit
of a demo of how it would work.
Any ideas?
Of course, this is Airbnb or air bed and
breakfast as it was originally called.
What about this one? Meet Matt. Matt
spots a girl he likes at a party, but
like most of us, Matt won't go over to
say hello. He has the problem most of us
do. Fear of rejection.
Any ideas?
Tinder, of course, originally called
Matchbox.
And finally, this one. Storage is a
mess. It's 2007 and it's still a pain to
work on multiple computers, share files
across a team, put photos, videos onto
the web, and protect files from loss.
Currently, people have to use email, USB
drives, browser uploads, and peacemail
solutions.
Ideally, your files would be available
wherever you are on any device. You'd
never worry about losing data, and you
can always undo it. And sharing and
putting media onto a web is just drag
and drop.
Of course, Dropbox keeps files in sync
across computers, backed up, accessible
from anywhere, and it's easy to share.
It just works.
So, who am I? Well, my name is Emily. As
I mentioned, I currently work for an
insurance company called I A in the
technology side of the business. I'm
currently in a team called insurance
platforms that looks after the
technology for all insurance related
claims and policies that happen
throughout the company and its brands.
This is an exciting place to be. There's
a lot of complex work happening with
lots of incredibly intelligent people
and a lot of money being spent on
software solutions.
I'm also a women in technology advocate.
Uh but outside of my day job, I own a
mobile coffee van. I started this mobile
coffee van in 2018 and quickly
acknowledged lots of problems in this
industry which sparked me to start up my
own business which previously called
Coffee Van Collective now called
Venderly is a software platform to help
event organizers find and manage mobile
coffee vendors and soon we'll be
launching uh that platform out to the
public and to event organizers
throughout this pitch.
presentation today. I will be sharing
with you some slides from Coffee Van
Collective um from a couple of pictures
that I've done over the last couple of
years. They're by no means perfect, but
hopefully they will give you a bit of an
insight into what types of things you
need to include in a pitch when you are
presenting to investors or judges or
partners or anyone really.
So, what goes into a pitch? Well, this
is a standardized, tried and tested
format for structuring your pitch. And
in a moment, I'll run through each of
these topics with some examples from my
pitches in the past. I can't claim that
the version I did is 100% perfect, but
it's a starting point. And there are
some good examples online for you to
look up also.
So, you'll see here there are sort of 10
or 11 things that generally go into a
pitch, but this will vary depending on
the time that you have available.
The most important ones are defining the
problem and defining your target market
to show that there is demand for your
problem and your solution.
So firstly the title slide.
This can be something really simple.
Just make it engaging and you don't need
to put too much on this. Just something
to let people know who you are.
Next, the vision.
Ideally, you have 10 seconds to engage
your audience. A quick overview of the
business for context setting and setting
out the vision. I like to include an
image on this slide. You'll see here
I've actually included a real life
example from one of the other coffee van
owners in my network.
So, Coffee Van Collective is a software
solution to simplify the operations of
the mobile vending community and to
facilitate bookings with event
organizers.
Next, I've just done a bit of an example
about me to set some context as to why
I've decided to go into this startup
opportunity. This really sets the tone
with the audience uh because they can
relate to why I'm really doing what I'm
doing. So for me, I acknowledge that I
started my coffee van business in 2018.
I grew my coffee van community network
with over 5,000 other vendors in
Melbourne and Perth and I run monthly
info webinars to help people in this
industry and to educate on how to
properly run a mobile coffee van. Uh I
also started a podcast last year which
provides that domain expertise and
allows investors to really get to grips
with my understanding of the industry. I
talk a little bit here about why I got
into mobile coffee vending and the
problems that I saw emerge throughout my
time.
But the next slide is where we really go
into the problem.
So here the increasing costs and
complexities of running a mobile trading
business are causing stress and
frustration and financial troubles to
emerging and existing vendors. This
slide should really demonstrate why do
you care. Do not include your solution
here. Be succinct and avoid buzzwords
like game changer. Have some factual
information and try to relay the problem
in a relatable way. Some of the judges
may not have experience with your
problem, so try to make them see it
through someone else's eyes.
Here I demonstrate that mobile coffee
vendors find it really hard to find
trading sites and or manage bookings.
The current options are slow,
ineffective, and clunky. They're
primarily done through Facebook groups,
Google searching, lots of liazing,
calling, emailing, and it causes a lot
of stress and wasted time for vendors
and event organizers and essentially
loss of profit at the end of the day.
I also think you can include a slide if
you have time around who we are doing
this for. I like to demonstrate very
clearly who are the users of our
solution. This actually gives our
audience a better understanding of who
we are doing this for and it's great to
demonstrate almost a c customer persona
type. So on my slide I've got our
independent mobile vendors. These people
struggle with managing inquiries,
liazing with organizers, and having a
central calendar to manage their all
their work. In my scenario, I've got
event organizers split into two
categories. The single event organizers
who often are volunteers, uh, you know,
footy club members or parents of a PNC,
and they don't know where to look to
find vendors. They need to be guided
through the process, and they want it to
be simple and efficient.
On the other end of the scale, we've got
large event organizers. Normally, these
people are pretty organized. They want
to be able to streamline their
expression of interest process and build
vendor management plans for upcoming
events. And finally, councils. Councils
struggle with the huge load of incoming
inquiries from both vendors and event
organizers. They want to be able to
easily access documentation like public
liability and make sure that compliance
is being followed for events within
their council. When I'm going through
this slide, I normally give these people
names. This helps to make it more
relatable for the audience, too. So, I
might say, "John from the footie club
needs some help finding a local coffee
vendor for the upcoming footy season."
That really makes it pop with the
audience.
So the next section is around our target
market.
Avoid defining your target market as
large as possible. Your target market is
not always your end user. If that's the
case, make that clear. Your target
market is the one who pays for what
you're offering. Here you're identifying
the market opportunity to succeed. You
want to include the demographics of your
target market. And this is where you're
telling the story about the scope and
the scale of the problem you are
solving. Now, it's very likely that you
will have to put some assumptions into
your market size. So, for example, I
have estimated that there are around
mobile coffee van bookings being made
every year. This has been done based on
the assumption that there are 25,000
uh mobile vendors in just one of the
Facebook groups that I'm a part of. And
I have then extrapolated that out across
the rest of Australia and assumed that
they are all trading on Saturday and
Sunday and they are getting on average
one booking per week. So, I make those
assumptions clear, but I also don't want
to overload the audience with a huge
load of numbers and confuse them. So, I
just put this simple stat on the page.
And I do tell them that there's the
opportunity to dive into these marketsiz
numbers after the pitch if they want to
connect with me.
Now, we talk about the solution.
Describe your product or service and how
customers use your product or service.
Why are you the one to solve the
problem? Make sure you are clear on how
it addresses the problem that you have
outlined. You can include your unique
selling point and you need to show that
your business has differentiation.
Photos, screenshots, prototypes
are really great things to use here to
demonstrate the solution that you have
built.
You'll see here on the slide I have got
an image on the right which is a
snapshot from my current platform just
to demonstrate what I'm trying to do.
Another way you can do this if you
haven't yet built the solution is to use
software like Figma or Canva or even
PowerPoint to just mock up what you are
trying to achieve.
Doesn't need to be too detailed just
something basic to demonstrate.
So here I say that our coffee van
collective solution is a holistic
support network. It's a search engine
and a booking platform and there's a
member profile to manage bookings and
access benefits. This provides more
transparency and security for both
vendors and hirers.
As well as that we're accessing the
power of the collective. We're providing
supply discounts to our members. We can
run sustainability initiatives which are
hard and expensive for for solo
operators and we can capture data that's
not captured anywhere else on this in
this industry.
Another slide that we like to include is
competition. It's important to make sure
that you've looked at what competition
is around you and demonstrated how you
are going to be different or better than
the competition.
So, what is your unique selling point?
Have a think and do some research on the
other products out there that are
similar. Remember, it doesn't always
matter that there are similar products
out there. This could actually help your
case if it proves that the concept is
working successfully elsewhere. For
example, Car Next Store, which was
acquired last year by Uber, first got
the idea when they saw it being
implemented effectively in Europe and
they realized that they could be a first
mover in the Australian market, but
following a similar business model.
So on the screen here, you'll see that I
have just put some of our major
competitors and ourselves into a matrix
against the cost and the functionality
of the solution.
You'll see that some of the current
solutions whilst they are cheap or free
like Facebook groups, they have low
functionality or they're clunky or
ineffective or inefficient.
Whereas some other options like for
example creating your own web site and
search engine optimization in the top
right there that has high functionality
for a mobile vendor but it's incredibly
uh costly to do that uh on your own. So
as a centralized platform coffee van
collective provides a unique value
proposition in that we can create a
real-time calendar view. We can provide
advanced data analytics to our members
to event organizers and vendors and also
supplier discounts and consultancy
services.
Next, we go into the business model.
The business model should demonstrate
how you are driving revenue. Is it a
membership or is it pay per use or is it
commission? What do you charge? Are you
a premium high price offering or a
budget offering that undercuts existing
solutions in the market? Again, this is
very heavily based on your assumptions
and lo and logic. So, make sure that
you're just creating something that's
simple but can clearly demonstrate how
much you anticipate spending to reach
your solution and when you anticipate
getting revenue from the services that
you are providing. Our model here, which
has changed significantly since we've
evolved into our new product, Venderly,
assumes that the revenue based on $29
per month and two bookings per van per
month. This suggests that we will have a
low or no code solution in year one.
We'll invest in a custom dev solution in
year two, which was about $50,000, which
would see us turn a profit in year
three. And then by adding additional re
revenue streams like consultancy
services, uh we would actually increase
our profit to 1.2 million over 5 years.
At the bottom of the slide, you'll just
see some highle steps that we anticipate
taking over the next five years. So
getting our branding and any trademarks
down, uh building our low code solution,
designing that product roadmap so we
know where we're heading, seeking
investment for custom dev solution, and
finally getting it out to market and
iterating as we go.
The next slide is all about traction.
It's important to demonstrate how you
are
reaching traction on your proposed
solution.
So this could be in the form of sales
units, revenue if you've already started
taking revenue, media coverage,
expressions of interest if you've run
any campaigns on Facebook or otherwise,
promises of distribution or stocks, the
number of paying customers, um,
basically any major goals that you've
achieved so far, and what your next
major steps you plan on taking. As you
can see here, I have demonstrated
traction by showing that we interviewed
a number of of uh interviewees and that
96% of them said that they would use our
proposed solution.
Of the webinars that I run every month,
90% of those attendees have already
pre-registered for the product uh
through a little survey that I've got.
And I've also demonstrated that there's
over 500 Google searches every month for
mobile coffee booking related searches.
So this Google search function is really
cool and really easy to do. You can go
into the analytics and insights
component of Google and just search in
there to see how many um Google searches
are happening on your specific topic or
solution that you are building.
Finally, I've demonstrated that there
are numerous posts on Facebook groups
looking for a mobile coffee vendor um
which demonstrates the demand that I
have for this solution. What would be
even better on this slide be able would
be me being able to show the number of
users that we have signed up already.
So, since doing this initial pitch, we
now have 20 users signed up on the
platform and we're building a new custom
dev solution. um for Venderly, our new
product, and we will be migrating those
20 users over to the platform once we
are ready.
So, we're almost at the end of the
presentation, but it's important to make
sure you include a slide about yourself
and the team that is building this
solution.
So, why would they want to work with
you? What gives you the ability to make
this a success? In my case, it's a deep
understanding of the problem or target
market, but in other people's case, they
might have a degree in computer science
or app development. Just play to your
strengths. You can also call out where
there are gaps that you are looking to
fill and how you plan to fill those. So
currently this this slide was done about
a year ago and I was looking for product
designers, developers or coffee vans or
small business lovers who wanted to join
me in making this a success. I now have
some advisers and mentors working with
me and I'm looking to bring in a tech
lead in the next few months.
And finally, we like to round out the
session with an ask.
So, this is a call to action. This is
your opportunity to ask your audience to
help you on this journey. If you're
looking for investment, make sure you
call out how much and why. You can call
out mentoring or advisory, any
connections you need, or any team
members that you're looking to hire.
This is just a good way to remind the
audience of what you need from them.
In your case, it might be pick me as the
winner of this competition.
And finally, just a thank you slide. I
like to put my contact details on this
slide so they can follow up. A QR code
to your LinkedIn is an absolute game
changer.
So, a few tips and tricks just to
finish. Don't read off the slides or a
script. Use the imagery to tell the
story. Be prepared for questions. Um, if
it's a video pitch, you can record your
PowerPoint presentation like I have done
here. Um, face the audience or the
camera. Use different variations in your
tone and emphasize important words and
try to speak clearly.
Try as hard as possible to enjoy it
because that will reflect into the
judg's decisions as well.
As I've got here on the screen, uh
formatting really does matter. Make sure
that your slides are well formatted, the
format, the font is correct, and that
you've got um similar styles across each
of the pages. Less is more. Remember,
people don't want to be reading off a
slide, especially if it is a short
presentation.
Focus on the problem and who you're
solving it for. Um, I did say not to
read off a script, but I do think it's
important to have a script written so
you know kind of what you're about to
about to say. Um, time your script so
that you know it fits within the time
slot and practice, practice, practice.
Um, it's always much more comforting to
know that you've practiced and you feel
prepared to give your pitch. And eye
contact is really important when giving
any sort of presentation or engaging
with an audience.
Normally this would be the part where
you ask questions but as this is a
recorded session I have just put my link
in here for you to follow up. Uh I'm
more than happy for you to connect with
me uh if you have any questions
following the presentation. Um but for
today that is all. Good luck with the
competition and I hope to see you next
time.
